title: The that song

multiple-choice.question: What is self-talk defined as in the context of psychology?

options.label: A
options.text: Verbalized thoughts directed toward others or external stimuli.

options.label: B
options.text: Verbalized thoughts directed toward oneself or some facet of one's life.

options.label: C
options.text: Non-verbalized thoughts directed toward oneself or some facet of one's life.

options.label: D
options.text: Thoughts that are only spoken when alone.

multiple-choice.question: According to Lev Vygotsky, what is the significance of self-talk in children's development?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a sign of mental instability.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a key to managing behaviors and emotions on their own.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a sign of intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a sign of creativity.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary benefit of engaging in self-talk that is instructional or motivational?

options.label: A
options.text: It decreases stress.

options.label: B
options.text: It increases focus, boosts self-esteem, and helps tackle everyday tasks.

options.label: C
options.text: It improves memory.

options.label: D
options.text: It increases anxiety.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential harm of engaging in negative self-talk?

options.label: A
options.text: It has no negative impact on mental health.

options.label: B
options.text: It can become toxic and predictive of anxiety and depression.

options.label: C
options.text: It can only harm one's physical health.

options.label: D
options.text: It can only harm one's relationships.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the field of psychological treatment that focuses on regulating the tone of self-talk?

options.label: A
options.text: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)

options.label: B
options.text: Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT)

options.label: C
options.text: Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR)

options.label: D
options.text: Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT)

title: Why some people are more altruistic than others - Abigail Marsh

multiple-choice.question: What was the reason behind the speaker's interest in understanding altruism?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand why people engage in selfish behavior.

options.label: B
options.text: To understand why people rescue strangers in life-threatening situations.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand the causes of his own near-death experience.

options.label: D
options.text: To understand the roots of extraordinary acts of altruism.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between psychopaths and extraordinary altruists?

options.label: A
options.text: Psychopaths are more likely to engage in violent behavior, while altruists are more likely to engage in non-violent behavior.

options.label: B
options.text: Psychopaths are less likely to recognize fearful facial expressions, while altruists are more likely to recognize them.

options.label: C
options.text: Psychopaths are more likely to have a larger amygdala, while altruists are more likely to have a smaller amygdala.

options.label: D
options.text: Psychopaths are more likely to be compassionate, while altruists are more likely to be uncaring.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key characteristic of extraordinary altruists that distinguishes them from the average person?

options.label: A
options.text: They are more likely to engage in self-centered behavior.

options.label: B
options.text: They are more likely to have a larger amygdala.

options.label: C
options.text: They have a lack of self-centeredness, or humility, which allows them to expand their circle of compassion to include strangers.

options.label: D
options.text: They are more likely to be insensitive to the suffering of others.

multiple-choice.question: What has been observed as a result of increases in wealth and standards of living?

options.label: A
options.text: A decrease in altruism towards strangers.

options.label: B
options.text: An increase in cruelty and violence.

options.label: C
options.text: An increase in altruism towards strangers, from volunteering to charitable donations and even altruistic kidney donations.

options.label: D
options.text: No change in altruism towards strangers.

multiple-choice.question: Why is there a common perception that the world is becoming worse and more cruel, despite evidence to the contrary?

options.label: A
options.text: Because people are becoming more selfish and less compassionate.

options.label: B
options.text: Because we now just know so much more about the suffering of strangers in distant places, and so we now care a lot more about the suffering of those distant strangers.

options.label: C
options.text: Because there is a lack of education and awareness about the suffering of others.

options.label: D
options.text: Because people are becoming less accepting of suffering in ever-widening circles of others.

title: Can you trust your ears? (audio illusions)

multiple-choice.question: What is the phenomenon where our visuals can alter what we believe we're hearing called?

options.label: A
options.text: The Trone Paradox

options.label: B
options.text: The Mcr Effect

options.label: C
options.text: The Shepher Tone Illusion

options.label: D
options.text: The Auditory Illusion

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the auditory illusion created by Diana Deutsch, where our brains have a preference of which frequency to listen to?

options.label: A
options.text: The Trone Paradox

options.label: B
options.text: The Mcr Effect

options.label: C
options.text: The Shepher Tone Illusion

options.label: D
options.text: The Tone Preference Illusion

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the illusion where a gradually climbing tune sounds like it's only continuing to climb higher and higher, even when played in reverse?

options.label: A
options.text: The Mcr Effect

options.label: B
options.text: The Trone Paradox

options.label: C
options.text: The Shepher Tone Illusion

options.label: D
options.text: The Tone Continuation Illusion

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the Shepher Tone Illusion, where multiple sine waves are played on top of one another raising in pitch while one quickly drops down an octave?

options.label: A
options.text: Our brain notices the drop in pitch and the tune sounds like it's stopping.

options.label: B
options.text: Our brain doesn't notice the drop in pitch and the tune sounds like it's rising forever.

options.label: C
options.text: The tune sounds like it's alternating between rising and falling in pitch.

options.label: D
options.text: The tune sounds like it's remaining the same pitch.

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Can Music Save Your Life?

options.label: D
options.text: The Effects of Music on Mental Health

title: Helping others makes us happier— but it matters how we do it - Elizabeth Dunn

multiple-choice.question: What was the researcher's initial finding about the relationship between giving money to charity and happiness?

options.label: A
options.text: Giving money to charity did not make a difference in happiness.

options.label: B
options.text: Giving money to charity made a small difference in happiness.

options.label: C
options.text: Giving money to charity made a significant difference in happiness, even after accounting for personal financial situation.

options.label: D
options.text: Giving money to charity had no correlation with happiness.

title: The Gauntlet | Think Like A Coder, Ep 8

multiple-choice.question: What is the main problem that Ethic and Hedge face in the canyon of brick and steel?

options.label: A
options.text: They are lost and need to find a way out.

options.label: B
options.text: They are being chased by a group of robots.

options.label: C
options.text: They need to find a way to reach the Node of Memory, which is located in the heart of the city.

options.label: D
options.text: They are out of food and need to find a way to get more supplies.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the gauntlet of forking paths that the group must navigate to reach the Node of Memory?

options.label: A
options.text: To test their physical strength and endurance.

options.label: B
options.text: To see how well they can work together as a team.

options.label: C
options.text: To find the one safe path that leads to the Node of Memory.

options.label: D
options.text: To distract the robots and give Ethic and Lemma time to escape.

multiple-choice.question: What is the special power that Hedge has been granted by the Node of Creation?

options.label: A
options.text: He can produce slightly larger versions of himself.

options.label: B
options.text: He can create complex mathematical equations to solve problems.

options.label: C
options.text: He can produce slightly smaller versions of himself, which can radio information back to their parent.

options.label: D
options.text: He can teleport himself and others to any location.

multiple-choice.question: What is recursion, and how is it used to solve the problem of finding the safe path to the Node of Memory?

options.label: A
options.text: Recursion is a type of loop that repeats a set of instructions until a certain condition is met.

options.label: B
options.text: Recursion is a type of function that refers back to itself, allowing it to repeat a set of instructions.

options.label: C
options.text: Recursion is a type of algorithm that uses a series of steps to solve a problem.

options.label: D
options.text: Recursion is a type of data structure that stores information in a hierarchical manner.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the action that every version of Hedge will follow to find the safe path to the Node of Memory?

options.label: A
options.text: Pathfinder

options.label: B
options.text: Explorer

options.label: C
options.text: Navigator

options.label: D
options.text: Guide

title: If your hands could smell, you’d be an octopus

multiple-choice.question: What helps an octopus's suckers stick so well?

options.label: A
options.text: Super glue

options.label: B
options.text: Water pressure

options.label: C
options.text: Strong muscles

options.label: D
options.text: Special skin cells

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: It tells the arms how fast to move

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: The importance of setting in a story

multiple-choice.question: What is the author of the transcript suggesting about the importance of setting in a story?

options.label: A
options.text: The setting is only important for the plot, not the mood or theme.

options.label: B
options.text: The setting can inform the mood and theme of a story.

options.label: C
options.text: The setting is not important at all in a story.

options.label: D
options.text: The setting is only important for the characters, not the plot or theme.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the author choose a cave as the setting for the story of Odysseus and the Cyclops?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was a random place.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was a common setting for ancient Greek stories.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it allowed Odysseus to be trapped and hide in the dark.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it was a place where the Cyclops was likely to live.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author suggesting about the relationship between the setting and the mood of a story?

options.label: A
options.text: The setting has no effect on the mood of a story.

options.label: B
options.text: The setting can create a dark and ominous mood.

options.label: C
options.text: The setting can create a light and hopeful mood.

options.label: D
options.text: The setting can create a mood that is opposite of the theme.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author suggesting about the importance of choosing a setting for a story?

options.label: A
options.text: The setting is not important, just choose a random place.

options.label: B
options.text: The setting is only important for the plot, not the mood or theme.

options.label: C
options.text: The setting should be chosen with care to inform the mood and theme.

options.label: D
options.text: The setting should be chosen based on the author's personal preference.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author suggesting about the relationship between the setting and the theme of a story?

options.label: A
options.text: The setting has no effect on the theme of a story.

options.label: B
options.text: The setting can create a theme that is opposite of the mood.

options.label: C
options.text: The setting can inform the theme of a story.

options.label: D
options.text: The setting is only important for the plot, not the theme.

title: Why do India and China have so many people?

options.text: Over 1 billion people

options.label: B
options.text: Over 2.7 billion people

options.label: C
options.text: Over 5 billion people

options.label: D
options.text: Over 10 billion people

options.label: A
options.text: Because they had a better education system

options.label: B
options.text: Because they had more fertile land and access to fresh water

options.label: C
options.text: Because they had a more advanced technology

options.label: D
options.text: Because they had a larger area of land

options.label: A
options.text: It allows for a large population to be sustained

options.label: B
options.text: It allows for a small population to be sustained

options.label: C
options.text: It has no impact on population growth

options.label: D
options.text: It allows for a population to be sustained, but not as large as in India and China

multiple-choice.question: Why did Pakistan and Bangladesh have smaller populations compared to India and China?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Because they had a smaller area of land

options.label: C
options.text: Because they had a less advanced technology

options.label: D
options.text: Because they had a worse education system

title: The bug that poops candy - George Zaidan

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the sieve tubes in a plant's plumbing system?

options.label: A
options.text: To transport water and minerals from the roots to the leaves.

options.label: B
options.text: To produce sugar through photosynthesis.

options.label: C
options.text: To transport sap, which is mostly water and sugar, from the leaves to the roots.

options.label: D
options.text: To store water and nutrients in the plant's cells.

multiple-choice.question: How does Mabel, the aphid, feed on plant sap?

options.label: A
options.text: By sucking it out of the plant using her stylet.

options.label: B
options.text: By piercing the sieve tubes and letting the pressure push the sap through her digestive system.

options.label: C
options.text: By using an enzyme to break down the sugar molecules in the sap.

options.label: D
options.text: By drinking the sap directly from the plant's cells.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the enzyme sucrase in Mabel's gut?

options.label: A
options.text: To break down the sugar molecules in the sap into simpler compounds.

options.label: B
options.text: To produce energy for Mabel from the fructose molecules.

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce the number of sugar molecules in the sap, making it less likely to suck water out of Mabel's cells.

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the amount of water in Mabel's cells.

multiple-choice.question: What is telescopic development in aphids?

options.label: A
options.text: A process where aphids can produce multiple generations within a single season.

options.label: B
options.text: A process where aphids can lay eggs that hatch into female nymphs.

options.label: C
options.text: A process where aphids can give birth to live young that are clones of themselves.

options.label: D
options.text: A process where aphids can produce honeydew.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the ants that herd and defend aphid colonies?

options.label: A
options.text: To eat the aphids and their honeydew.

options.label: B
options.text: To protect the aphids from other predators.

options.label: C
options.text: To collect the honeydew from the aphids and drink it directly.

options.label: D
options.text: To harvest the sap from the plants.

options.label: C

options.label: C

title: Embrace the Shake - Phil Hansen

multiple-choice.question: What was the artist's initial reaction to developing a shake in his hand while in art school?

options.label: A
options.text: He was excited to try new techniques.

options.label: B
options.text: He was devastated, fearing it would ruin his artistic career.

options.label: C
options.text: He was indifferent, thinking it wouldn't affect his art.

options.label: D
options.text: He was thrilled to have a new form of self-expression.

multiple-choice.question: What did the artist's neurologist suggest he do with his shake?

options.label: A
options.text: Try to stop it completely.

options.label: B
options.text: Embrace the shake and use it as a form of self-expression.

options.label: C
options.text: Use medication to control the shake.

options.label: D
options.text: Focus on drawing straight lines to compensate for the shake.

multiple-choice.question: What was the artist's approach to creating art after realizing he was limited by his shake?

options.label: A
options.text: He tried to find ways to work around his limitations.

options.label: B
options.text: He gave up on art and focused on other creative pursuits.

options.label: C
options.text: He experimented with new techniques that took advantage of his shake.

options.label: D
options.text: He stuck to traditional methods and hoped his shake would go away.

multiple-choice.question: What was the title of the artist's year-long project where he created art that had to be destroyed after its creation?

options.label: A
options.text: "Goodbye Art"

options.label: B
options.text: "The Shake"

options.label: C
options.text: "Limitations"

options.label: D
options.text: "Embracing the Shake"

multiple-choice.question: What was the artist's ultimate realization about embracing his limitations?

options.label: A
options.text: That it would lead to greater success and recognition.

options.label: B
options.text: That it would make him more confident in his abilities.

options.label: C
options.text: That it would allow him to tap into a new source of creativity and inspiration.

options.label: D
options.text: That it would help him learn to let go of outcomes, imperfections, and outcomes.
